posts.author: webshaman1

I would  recommend The Gloom Razor - gloom-razor-of-the-hin-rogue-24-divine- ... 55280.html by grizzled_dwarflord for a WoG first time explorer. It covers all the bases (skills, AB, AC, offensive, defensive) without having to rely on meta-knowledge of items and places to survive imo.
There is a footnote in the annals of halfling history that reference an ancient line of warlike halflings.  Chief amongst them were the Gloom Razors, divine warrior scouts who were unmatched in combat.  Dauntless, fearless, these Hin Warlords were the premier knights of the Gloom Brigade, for they dwelt in the Gloaming, the twilight, but this is just a footnote in the old Hin annals, and likely nothing more than the fancy musings of a halfling historian deep in his cups….
 

IMG_0160.JPG (82.01KiB)


Peerless in combat and virtually unhittable, the Gloom Razor launches a terrifying assault from darkness, with 6 attacks per round, 12d6 sneak per blade, coupled with Epic Weapon Specialization, Crippling Strike, Improved Knockdown and/or Called Shot to shred your opponent to bits.

Strengths
·       Epic Dodge and Undispellable Self Concealment 50%
·       High AC
·       Very Good AB for Dual-wielder with high rogue levels
·       With a small bump to Dex, can eventually set Epic Traps
·       Disable all traps
·       UMD for Wand and Scroll Casting
·       Versatile Offensive Toolkit – can launch 12d6 sneak with Crippling Strike, and can supplement it with Called Shot or IKD 6 times per round.
·       The build matures early and often
 
Weaknesses
·       Fort Save, while respectable, still susceptible to Dev Crit (if the enemy can connect)
·       Will Save.  While pretty respectable for a finesse build, can still be a concern
·       Beware of IGMS trebuchets
·       No HiPS safety blanket
 
Combat Strategies
·       From a stealthed position, launch an IKD on your opponent.  If successful, begin to land Called Shot: Arm attacks, combined with Crippling Strike, and when your opponent gets back on his feet, if he gets back on his feet, he will have jello arms.  You’ll be able to knock down again, which he will be more susceptible since his strength will be lowered.
·       Mine the combat field with traps to disable and weaken your opponent
·       Never fight fair
 
Sneak Attack Generation
·       From your initial Stealth position
·       Source of Invisibility (Potion, Wand, Item, Scroll)
·       Corner Stealth – running behind a corner or object that interrupts line of sight and then re-enter stealth mode
·       Flanking – allowing a party member to tank
·       More Flanking – use scroll or wand (or item) casting to create summons to give you flanking opportunities
·       Improved Knockdown – every flurry is a sneak on a knock-downed opponent
 
Similar Builds:
·       Halfling Commando by Xylophone: This is a slinger with no SC V or dual-wielding and significantly lower melee AB
 
·       Drowkiller: Human and much lower AB and lower saves
 
·       Martial Rogue:  Less Sneak, much lower AB, no dual-wielding or SC V
 
·       Shadow Sword: A TyrTemplar special, but lacks Crippling Strike, over 80 skill points less, no IKD or Called Shot, and doesn’t use sexy kukris
 
·       And then Mick Dagger’s well-considered Halfling Champion: Similar, but lacks SC V and Crippling Strike, less skill points, and doesn’t get Epic Dodge until Lvl 32.  In it’s favor it gets 1 higher AB, 1 higher AC, and more HP.  But still a much different build since he focuses on Discipline to go toe to toe with strength builds.
 
·       And then there is my own slew of Fighter/Rogue/CoT’s: Death’s Rival, The Last Great Bounty Hunter, and the Incredible Fighting Rogue of War, but they’re all Dwarves, so… I won’t bother posting links for those.
 
Builder’s Commentary
While I hesitate to call anything the “quintessential” build of something, this is fairly close to being one to represent the halfling rogue warrior clan.  There are many varied combinations of these classes – a testament to the versatility of this combo – but somehow this one manages to be different.  Of course, when you play this game long enough at some point you feel like you’re “jumping the shark” when building any kind of class combo anymore.  Many (me included) will often argue the value and investment of something like Self Concealment V since it is such a huge investment – 5 feats – and coming at the expense of other things that you would like to see your Rogue have (Epic Will, Slippery Mind, Epic Fort, Great Dex’s, Improved Sneaks or Epic Skill Foci).  Indeed, I remade this same character and removed the SC feats and achieved an unbuffed dualwielding AB of 44, which is outstanding for no WM or RDD levels while still retaining 24 Rogue levels.
 
But there is still something sexy about SC V.  It’s baked in.  It’s permanent.  There’s no mitigation for it (save Blindfighting).  If the enemy’s first attack is an IKD, and he lands the hit, Epic Dodge makes it miss.  His second attack is now coming at 5 lower AB, which is like adding 5 to your AC.  Assuming he can still land that, Self Concealment takes over and now his hit is half as likely to miss.  Epic Dodge, coupled with high AC and SC feats, makes you nigh untouchable.
 
Kukri’s were taken because they’re far sexier than daggers, and they can be keened and have a higher crit range.  However, Improved Crit is not taken because of the diminishing return on that investment.  Still, you could drop Called Shot, or Iron Will, if you feel you must have it.  I don’t think it adds much in a build like this.
 
I rarely take Called Shot in a non-archer build, but it works in this one.  It’s a nice tool to have for both ranged and melee tactics, especially of the enemy is either to large to knockdown or has immunity/discipline resistance.
 
While I invested points in Discipline, you may find yourself not needing it and rely on Epic Dodge and Concealment (and KD Immunity) to avoid the best attack sequence from your enemies.  If you’re swarmed by more than two opponents with such attacks, you may reconsider that decision though.  Just know that enemies with Disarm/Improved Disarm may have a leg up on you, especially if they’re using medium or large weapons.
 
Spellcraft was cross-classed (yes, you have that many skill points) to help out in the saves department (+4 extra against spells).
 
Finally, there is something satisfying in how well the build matures.  It gradually and consistently becomes stronger, faster, better, and never seems to lack.  In fact, there is a sweet spot from Level 27 to Level 33 where, in a span of 6 levels, he grabs Epic Dodge, Crippling Strike, EWF, EWS, Epic Prowess, and SC I and SC II.  I do miss the days when one could take Epic Dodge at Level 21, but those days are gone.  Level 27 is as early as one can get it, and really should be the target one shoots for when building an Epic Dodger.
I myself have played the build to level 40 on WoG, and I know that GDL has tested it there.  The most important part of the build, imo (besides having ALL the skills and abilities necessary to survive on WoG all in a level 1-40 playable package) is the level 27 to 33 "explosion" of abilities built into the build that comes exactly when one will be needing them most!
All in all, a most enjoyable, incredible build, from the master builder himself, a known player of WoG.
It will not disappoint.

posts.author: webshaman1

So I took my Gloomy out for a spin, just to make sure that with all the changes having been done to WoG, that the build still performs as it used to...

YUP!

Wow, I had forgotten just how sick the build is!

Took her up to have tea with some stonies (Stone Giants).  Took them all on at once! (which is just asking for it - it's like bursting into a Bandito's bar and pissing on their boots) >.<

She mopped the floor with'em! O_o

Now, this area had been changed, and is a lot moar challenging than it used to be - new foes (Cloppy Warpriests, eldar riftlords - both with multiple rez castings), and of course swarm AI.

Which means I ended up killing Trok, the Chieftain of the Stone Giants a total of 5 times (because rez) all the while fending off 10 Trokkie Bodyguards, an assortment of cloppy and lord casters, many stonies and an enraged thorned dragon!

And only used 1 Heal.

So yeah, Gloomrazor is still "teh mega Chizz" on WoG.

Good building, GDL!

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
As GDL plays regularly on WoG, and tests his builds there as well, it probably will perform as expected.

Namely, superb.

I will say this, though - I have never played it, and wouldn't on WoG.

The AB is too low.

It does have survivability (epic dodge and epic damage reduction), but I think it just sacrifices too much for defense for an environment like WoG, where higher AB is necessary.

As for it "out performing" a dedicated melee-er, that is a bit too much hubris imo.  Certainly I have some dedicated melee-ers that would pound it into the dirt, but I digress.  In an environment like WoG, where having a 6o+ AB is a solid melee-er, this build seems a bit low to me.

But for survivability, yeah, this is a good, solid build, no doubt about it.

As GDL also mentions that he plays this often in a party, I rather suspect that the AB deficit is easy to get around (buffs, ect), so there is that.  And also, most SP environments are not as demanding as WoG, so there is that as well.

Commentary
I�m not sure if there is an actual niche for this kind of build, so I thought I�d post it anyway. This build is for all those PWs out there that have made happy adjustments to the Shadowdancer class. I�ve played in several now where Shadow Evade has been given some actual use, and the duration is based on level, or have given Shadowdaze more teeth, or have altered the Shadowlord summons, and so on. Even if HiPS has been changed, given a cool-down period, or nerfed outright, this kind of character can still enjoy success. To explain the goal of this kind of character, it�s simply to maximize the utilities of the Shadowdancer class while still maintaining a healthy melee presence.

Basically, we wanted an assassin-like character, except instead of using Death Attack, we use Dev Crit. We maximize SD levels to give us the most out of Shadow Evade and to grab that great DR it grants at higher levels, as well as that juicy Shadowdaze DC. Even in Full Plate this character will have the same steath score as if he were naked and dex-based with a 26 Dex. We use the the SD bonus feats in a way one not normally sees SD feats used�for Epic Skill Focus feats. With 5 of those coming in Epic levels, there is lots of room for customization. Hide and Move Silently are a must, and the 3rd I nodded to the Epic Summons, and then I choose Taunt and Discipline because those things are important to me and my playstyle. I can easily see someone giving those up for Listen/Spot or UMD/Search, etc�.

I�ve done this kind of character before, such as in The Assassin King or the Zhentarim Field Agent, in which Strength-based stealthers launch from the shadows to lay waste with their sneak attacks. Since it hasn�t been done this way, I thought I�d post the full-blooded SD version. I�ve done other versions that were also quite fun, and did a Halfling version (had to swap Rogue for Bard) that got an even better Stealth score. Dwarf also works well with this, but you have to give up 43 skill points. The non-Dev Crit version got a slightly better AB and finished with Improved Expertise and Improved Disarm, which may be a nice option if Dev Crit is banned on your server. If Shadowdancers haven�t been given incentives to go deeper into levels on your PW, then this build may not be for you, though would still be playable and unique.

Halberd was chosen for coolness factor, though admittedly Greatsword would be better for crit efficiency. What�s nice about the Halberd is that it does to damage types, and 1.69 finally got that 2 damage type bug fixed. Comments and flames welcome. Cheers.
